messageBody:
Once again, what I've done in the past is create the
directories and files in setUp() and removed them in
tearDown(). Depends on how complex the files and
directory structure needs to be, I suppose. Having
explicit error messages about what is missing *is*
very helpful if you're relying on the files and/or
directories being there already.

-Eric

--- Erik Hanson <ehanson@...> wrote:
> "David V. Olivier" <dolivier@...> wrote:
> > The rule of thumb is that unit tests should be as
> standalone as possible,
> > and dependencies on external resources such as
> databases or files should be
> > minimized or eliminated. [...] However, code does
> touch
> > external resources at some point. Shouldn't this
> be tested, and how?
> >
> > Specifically, I have code that parses a xml
> catalog file and builds a
> > catalog object structure. I want to verify that
> the parsing works
> > correctly.
> > [...]
> > But to do this test I do need some external
> resource, a simple catalog
> > file.
>
> What I do in this case is embed the contents of the
> file in the test as a
> string constant and use that for testing.
>
> However, sometimes I think you do have to rely on
> external resources. For
> example, I wrote a Java class that iterates over all
> files in a directory and
> its subdirectories. To test it, I need to either
> have real files and
> direcotories, or somehow use mock objects to
> simulate the files and
> directories. But the class is simple enough that the
> thing I'm really testing
> is that I understand correctly how Java's file I/O
> stuff works. So if I made a
> file I/O mock object, I'd still want to write a test
> for it which uses real
> files and directories.
>
> My solution is to put really good error messages in
> my tests. "Couldn't find
> file 'abc'. (This test requires that the following
> directory structure exists:
> ...)".
>
>
> Erik
>
>
